author: Alberto Olivas

comments.message: Also, could have a UV light to disinfect hands (on the wall like  a public bathroom hand dryer) so healthcare workers could sterilize their gloves before taking off their gear.
How would you protect the patients being exposed to high-strength UV light?

I'm thinking it would have to always be an affirmatively activated feature as opposed to having an automatic setting as I initially described it. Partly to avoid accidental activation while the light is pointed at one's own face/eyes, or when nearby children, seated persons, etc. So the activator should prevent accidental activation by requiring more than just a push button, perhaps a twist-and-push button, or a double or triple tap to activate?

description: The device will need to be small and lightweight enough not to be obstructive to the work of healthcare professionals. It should have a rechargeable battery, perhaps recharged by the motion of the wearer as they walk, gesture, etc.
summary: Liquid and gel hand sanitizers are expensive and bulky to transport and have to be replenished. An inexhaustible alternative could be a small clip on UV device that can be attached to a sleeve or bracelet on the dominant hand that can destroy pathogens on or near the hand(s), especially during handshakes, or handling hazardous material. It can be activated by a bluetooth remote control button worn on the opposite hand or wrist, or set to automatically activate when the hand is raised, such as when shaking hands at a meeting or large function. This would also effectively make the hand a portable sterilization device for anything you are pointing at.
title: Clip on UV light for hand sterilization
